sheets.Sheet1.Name: Cristiano Ronaldo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It is a measure of Cristiano Ronaldo's astonishingly consistent excellence that a year in which he won the Champions League with Real Madrid before captaining Portugal to victory at Euro 2016 is widely considered to have been a quiet one by his own preposterously high standards. While his apparently insatiable desire to make everything from the most informal dressing-room team photo to the highlight reels of the biggest football spectacles all about him may grate more often than amuse, it is difficult to ignore the reality that football's most preening showman is rarely found wanting ... even on the rare occasions he is found wanting. Having failed to score in the Champions League final, he stepped up to fire home the decisive spot-kick in the shootout. After limping off in the first half of Portugal's win over France in the Euro 2016 decider, he appointed himself de facto coach to roar, gesticulate and will his less talented team-mates to victory against the hosts. The No1 choice of just over half of our 122 judges, this was not one of Ronaldo's better years and he has still managed to end it with his fourth Ballon d'Or award, almost a decade after being presented with his first.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Lionel Messi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “There should be a Ballón d’Or for him and another one for all the other players,” Jorge Sampaoli said recently. Messi has set the bar so high, made the ridiculous so routine, that a year (by mid-December) in which he produced the most goals (59) and assists (36), in which he completed more dribbles than anyone else, became Xavi and Messi rolled together, won a league and cup double and took Argentina to a third final in a row, is judged a disappointment somehow. He would have thought so too when he missed that penalty at the Copa América. So much so that afterwards, he said that he was going to give up on international football, only to change his mind – to everyone’s relief. Without him, Argentina have looked bereft and when World Cup qualification was on the line (it still is), he stepped up to rescue them with a goal and two assists against Colombia. Superb throughout 2016, he has started this new club season in astonishing form, his game at Sevilla absolutely mind-blowing – even by his ludicrous standards. He has started to “Di Stéfano”, one newspaper said, playing everywhere and as everything. His range of passing all over the pitch, always better than anyone else’s but hidden behind the goals, the dribbles and the assists, is getting talked about at last. There may never have been a player who can do much as him; the best No10, 7, 8, 11 and 4 all wrapped in one.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Luis Suárez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The best of the “other” players after a season in which at club level he could even make a case to have been better than the “other two”. “When Neymar and Messi play, I try to get out the way,” he said, but on the final day of a league season which had begun with him scoring the only goal, his hat-trick clinched the title. That was appropriate: he got more goals and more assists than anyone in Spain in 2015-16. His 40 La Liga goals were more than anyone else has ever scored – apart from Messi and Ronaldo – and it was the first time one of them had not been top scorer in seven years. He scored regularly in the Champions League too and, by mid-December, he was just three short of 100 Barcelona goals.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Antoine Griezmann
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: No one would have been surprised if the 25-year-old had been too jaded to shoulder his country's attacking burden at Euro 2016. After all, he went into the tournament on the back of a hyper-productive club campaign, scoring 32 goals in 57 matches as Atlético Madrid took the La Liga title race to the line and reached the final of the Champions League. Griezmann was instrumental in both those odysseys, providing much of the art and sharpness to Diego Simeone's dynamic machine. He scored goals in the Champions League quarter-final win against Barcelona and the semi-final elimination of Bayern Munich but missed a penalty in extra time of the final against Real Madrid before netting in the losing shootout. After all that he made a slow start to Euro 2016, deployed wide on the right in France's first match and dropped for the second. But in the third he took charge of his country's attack and ended the tournament with the golden boot and a host of new admirers.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Neymar
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Down two places to fifth, Neymar has not quite pushed on as expected after a magnificent 2015. He might be No1 one day. But not yet. Not without greater consistency. This is not to say that Neymar has had a bad year. By the standards of most players, it has been wildly successful. Not content with helping Barcelona to win La Liga and the Copa del Rey again, he also knocked home the deciding penalty as Brazil, under pressure on home soil, claimed Olympic gold in men’s football for the first time in their history, and he has been in excellent goalscoring form for his country in World Cup qualifying since the summer. The spotlight was on Neymar when Messi and Argentina visited Belo Horizonte last month. He was on the scoresheet in a 3-0 win for Brazil. Yet he has not performed at his usual high level for Barcelona this season, scoring only six goals by mid-December, and there has been a little weariness to his play. There have been legal problems off the pitch, his schedule has been relentless in the past few years and it is worth remembering that he is the youngest member of Barcelona’s hallowed attacking trident. Do not be surprised if the 24-year-old returns better than ever in 2017.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gareth Bale
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For Gareth Bale, the rise of 10 places to sixth in the list reflects how he has eradicated any lingering doubts about his A-list credentials – although an ankle injury now means he will have to wait another couple of months before asserting them further. There was a point last year when Bale seemed unhappy at Real Madrid, little more than a support act as the Cristiano Ronaldo show rolled on, and Manchester United’s ears pricked up when the Bernabéu crowd whistled the Welshman for not passing to his illustrious team-mate in May 2015. But they don’t do that any more. Few players are as devastating as the Welshman when he sets off on one of those rampaging runs, demolishing defences with the explosiveness of his dribbling, confounding goalkeepers with that gorgeous left foot, and he has accepted more responsibility in a year when Ronaldo has been slightly less present for Real. His leadership qualities rose to the surface in the Champions League final against Atlético Madrid, when he ignored the cramp to convert his penalty in the shootout, then when he chipped in with three goals as Wales made history by reaching the last four at Euro 2016. There were two ways for Bale to respond to the critics. Come on, though. Did you really think he would let them win?

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Robert Lewandowski
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Robert Lewandowski is not the sort of player who talks about himself a lot but people close to the Polish striker will tell you that he harbours a secret, great ambition: he wants to be considered the best player in the world. In the era of Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi, that will not be easy for the 28-year-old. Pure centre-forwards, adept at leading the line and scoring goals on an industrial scale, are also not as universally revered – nor indeed valued by coaches – as they were before the advent of the highlight-reel commandeering attacking midfielder/striker hybrids. Two more of that mould, Antoine Griezmann and Gareth Bale, have moved ahead of him in the ranking, even though his own performances for club and country have been just as devastating as in previous seasons. His five goals in the space of nine minutes as a substitute against VfL Wolfsburg in January broke four world records. More recently, he has added goals from free-kicks to his oeuvre. Orthodox No9s who concentrate on the most important thing in football, the getting-the-ball-over-the-line bit, might be in danger of going out of fashion, but Lewandowski’s specialist skill-set, the combination of superb athleticism and sublime finishing, is so impressive that he is single-handedly bucking the trend.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The man who might have joined Tottenham Hotspur in 2013 if the club’s negotiation style had not put him off keeps getting better and better, as reflected in his 19-place year-on-year rise up the Top 100 chart. He is now perhaps the most sought-after striker in the world, continually linked with a record-breaking move away from Borussia Dortmund. Amid the speculation he scores relentlessly thanks to a unique mix of cuteness, deftness and phenomenal speed. The Gabon international is integral to Dortmund's thrilling attack and has become the most prolific non-German marksman in Dortmund's history, surpassing Robert Lewandowski's tally for the club. The Pole, however, beat Aubameyang into second place in the Bundesliga scoring tables last season as Bayern Munich romped to the title, a fact the Dortmund player set about trying to correct when he scored twice on the opening day of the new campaign. Despite Aubameyang's importance to Dortmund, the club's manager, Thomas Tuchel, dropped him when he made an unauthorised excursion to Milan in November. In his first game after that he netted four in a 5-2 win over Hamburg. He also scored home and away against Real Madrid as Dortmund topped their Champions League group.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Alexis Sánchez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: When Alexis Sánchez hurt his hamstring during a training session with Chile in November and it quickly became apparent that they would play him in the World Cup qualifier against Uruguay one week later, the angst that emanated from Arsenal knew no bounds. Arsène Wenger caught the mood, warning that it could be a “suicidal decision”. The thought of the club’s talisman breaking down was too horrible to bear and, when Sánchez did play, he did so with the prayers of everybody associated with Arsenal. This is how the forward is perceived these days. He has become central to the Arsenal formation, in his new role as the No9, and he is indispensable to their cause. Sánchez makes things happen, through his direct and explosive style and, moreover, through his relentlessness and the sheer force of his personality. His move this season from the flank to the centre, Thierry Henry-style, has made him even more of a threat and, having lifted the Copa América with Chile (again), he is obsessed by winning the title with Arsenal. A footnote: Sánchez scored two in Chile’s 3-1 victory against Uruguay. Nobody should have worried.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Riyad Mahrez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Behold a player who is not supposed to exist in modern football. Bought for buttons and built like a rag doll, Mahrez was the most treasured performer in the Premier League last season, the deserving recipient of the PFA player of the year award following his delightful role in Leicester's sensational title triumph. His skills were among the most charming parts of the Leicester story and he used them with selfless economy: not a player for showboating even though he could entertain crowds with his trickery, he invariably chooses the right moments to flash his nimble footwork or simply play one-touch passes like the pair that led to goals for Jamie Vardy against Manchester City in December. That match marked a renewal of the double act that thrilled the Premier League last term, when Mahrez scored 17 league goals on top of making an abundance of them for others. After spurning opportunities to leave the King Power in the summer, he helped his team make a triumphant debut in the Champions League, as Leicester finished top of their group and set up a last-16 duel with Sevilla. Claudio Ranieri refers to Mahrez simply as “our special player”, and voters agreed that he was among the world's top 10 performers this year.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Agüero
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Manchester City forward is one of the most dangerous attackers in the world, and not only when David Luiz is around. In a way his tendency to lose the run of himself when in proximity to Chelsea’s Brazilian defender highlights how cool he is normally, especially in the box, where he is as cold-blooded a predator as can be. His movement is brilliant and so is his ability to work space rapidly for a precise, powerful shot. He had the best goals-per-game ratio in the Premier League this year again, and was the second highest scorer in the Copa América.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Luka Modric
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: One of the most elegant players in Europe and the man who makes Real Madrid tick with his silkiness in possession. The midfielder was pivotal again as Real won the Champions League for the second time in three years, beating Atlético Madrid in the final in May, and he impressed during the Euros, scoring a lovely volleyed winner in their opener against Turkey. Croatia’s defeat to Portugal in the last 16 was a blow, but Modric has not let it affect him. Highly valued by Zinedine Zidane, he has risen 19 places after managing to avoid the kind of injuries that held him back last year.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Kevin De Bruyne
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Belgian’s importance to Manchester City can be summed up by the way their form deteriorated when he injured his knee in January. City fell out of the title race and it was a mark of his quality that he showed no rustiness after his return to the side in April, sparking the Champions League quarter-final win against Paris Saint-Germain. If there was one thing missing from his year, it was a better showing for Belgium at Euro 2016, but he has done well for his club. Although he has not been prolific this season, he has scored in wins against Barcelona and Manchester United.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gonzalo Higuaín
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Armchair pundits poked fun at Higuaín after he showed up for his first pre-season with Juventus looking decidedly overweight, but you will not find many defenders who would dare do the same. The Argentinian broke a 66-year-old record by scoring 36 goals in Serie A last season – at an astonishing rate of one for every 82.3 minutes played. Juventus duly paid €90m (£75m) to trigger his release clause at Napoli, and if they did have any initial concerns about his conditioning, then those – just like his excess pounds – are rapidly melting away under a deluge of decisive strikes.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Andrés Iniesta
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Pep Guardiola says he “masters space and time” and Luis Enrique describes him as “pure magic”, and Andrés Iniesta is now taking on responsibility for what Xavi used to do as well as what he still does. His return from injury recently was treated as the return of football itself, and no wonder. Even Lionel Messi says that when things are going wrong what he most wants is Iniesta closer to him. Luis Enrique admits that, at 32, he is protecting him now – because when it comes to the big games he is irreplaceable. His display in the Copa del Rey final was sublime.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: N'Golo Kanté
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Claudio Ranieri said that the Frenchman performed the role of two players during his one and only season at Leicester, which is why the club's fans dubbed him “the Kanté twins”. The nickname referred to a capacity to cover more ground than is possible for most players, tackling, intercepting and passing with incredible dynamism. His pivotal role in Leicester's progress to the title earned him a call-up to his national team – for whom he scored on his first start, against Holland in March. It later earned him a transfer to Chelsea and, as if that is not enough, the honour of being the highest new entry in this year's Top 100. The void in Leicester's midfield since his departure bears eloquent testimony to his ability.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Paul Pogba
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Shortly after his 23rd birthday he won his fourth successive Serie A title, playing his most influential role yet for Juventus. He struck his highest league goal tally and finished the season as the league’s joint highest provider of assists. That led to him becoming the figurehead of France’s Euro 2016 campaign. He failed to live up to that billing but that did not put off Manchester United, who were so convinced of his talent that they paid a world-record transfer fee to bring him back to Old Trafford. His influence there has grown as the season has advanced.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Manuel Neuer
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Neuer’s position as the world’s barely disputed supreme No1 may not quite be on as firm ground as last year but he is still the highest-placed goalkeeper on this list, and the highest-ranked German, even if the halo has dislodged ever so slightly. Now 30, the model sweeper-keeper is perhaps a more toned-down presence now but there remain few as good with the ball at their feet and few who can bail their team out so reliably with a reflex save, too. A few mistakes have crept in at home and abroad – Germany were already 1-0 down against France in their Euro 2016 semi-final when he pawed Paul Pogba’s cross to Antoine Griezmann but that put the game beyond them – but he had been their shoot-out hero against Italy a round previously. He remains the best in the business.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jamie Vardy
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A non-league player with Stocksbridge Park Steels as a 23-year-old, Vardy capped an improbable rise to the upper echelons of his sport in a year when he spearheaded Leicester City's fairytale title win, scored for England at Euro 2016 and made his Champions League debut. His autobiography revealed some rather unorthodox drinking habits and his pre-match port habit helped him score 24 Premier League goals as Leicester pulled off one of the greatest upsets in sporting history. He has found them harder to come by in recent months – although a hat-trick against Manchester City this month saw him back in business – and he may be ruing his decision to turn down a summer move to Arsenal.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Zlatan Ibrahimovic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: He is 35 now, the Swede, but still the goals keep coming, His fourth season in France with Paris Saint-Germain was arguably his best and he set a new club record with an incredible 50 goals during the 2015-16 season. His first few months at Manchester United have been mixed: he got off to a flying start with five goals in his first five games but then struggled for form. However, by 15 December he had scored 14 goals (nine more than the second-highest scorer, Juan Mata). He drops 13 places on the list, perhaps partly because he did not have a good Euro 2016.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Toni Kroos
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Kroos has seemed like a man liberated since the insertion of Casemiro, the defensive midfielder, into Zinedine Zidane’s Real Madrid side. He did not start particularly well at the Bernabéu after arriving in 2014, often finding himself foraging much closer to his own defence than he would like, but having protection behind him has allowed him to rediscover his groove. Kroos is at his best when allowed to move upfield and set the tempo of a contest with a dazzling range of passes; on top form there are few more compelling all-round midfielders in the sport and renewed evidence of that is the reason for this year’s move back up the charts.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gianluigi Buffon
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For Buffon, age really is just a number. He will turn 39 in January, but a more compelling figure by which to judge his enduring talent would be the 974 minutes that he went without conceding a goal in Serie A between January and March – a new record for the Italian top flight. Afterwards he posted an ode to his goal on Facebook, promising to carry on protecting it “as long as my legs, head and heart will allow”. On this evidence, it might be a while yet: our panel ranked him a full 12 places higher than in 2015.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mesut Özil
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: If you love football, you love Mesut Özil, according to Arsène Wenger, his manager at Arsenal, and the German has long been the connoisseur’s choice. The midfielder’s touch is velvety, luxurious and, when he is on his game – gliding into spaces, finessing angles – it is a mesmerising sight. But Özil has worked hard to add strength and power in order to cope with the demands of the Premier League and, most encouragingly for Arsenal, there has been the evidence of greater end product. The assist-meister has already scored more goals this season than in any of his previous three in north London.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Diego Godín
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Perhaps getting noticed at last, climbing 15 places in our poll after a season that ended with Atlético reaching another Champions League final – and ending it without conceding a goal, only to lose on penalties. “It’s hard to take but we’ll get up again,” Godín said. Nicknamed the Pharaoh, he has been at the heart of Atlético Madrid’s extraordinary success under Diego Simeone. The Uruguayan captain recently received in parliament the country’s highest distinction, the Premio José Nasazzi-Obdulio Varela – named after the captains of Uruguay’s 1930 and 1950 World Cup-winning sides – but he could not lead his team out of the group at the Copa América.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Ramos
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Ramos’s taste for tattoos has extended to red numbers inked onto his fingers but defending is the art with which he is more readily associated. And not only that: there are few defenders around with his ability to attack balls in the opposition box and make the difference at crucial times. His dramatic equaliser at Camp Nou last month might just prove decisive in the title race; another last-minute intervention got Real Madrid out of a tight spot against Deportivo two weeks later and he also saved them from Uefa Super Cup defeat against Sevilla at the death. The 30-year-old, as consistent as ever in his own box, does not always win friends through his mastery of the dark arts but has a wonderfully keen sense of theatre.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Leonardo Bonucci
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Pep Guardiola named Bonucci as ”one of my favourite ever players” in February. The rest of the world got a glimpse as to why when the Juventus defender undid Belgium with a spectacular 40-yard assist for Emanuele Giaccherini in Italy’s Euro 2016 opener four months later. Regular observers could attest that this was no isolated incident. A former midfielder (and even, briefly, an attacker) in his academy days, Bonucci might own the best passing range of any centre-back in Europe’s top five leagues. His finishing is not bad either, and he has scored some crucial goals for Juventus already in 2016-17.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Dimitri Payet
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Never mind bubbles, West Ham spent the year blowing kisses at Payet, whose wizardry even enraptured neutrals as Slaven Bilic’s side secured European qualification. Even Didier Deschamps found new affection for the midfielder and recalled him after a nine-month absence from the international scene just in time for Euro 2016, where he was one of France’s best players, scoring a wonderful winning goal against Romania in the opening match before finding the net again against Albania and Iceland. His creativity embellished the play of his club and his country while his free-kicks were stand-alone works of art.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Philippe Coutinho
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Contrary to received wisdom, Liverpool knew exactly what they had lost the moment Philippe Coutinho damaged ankle ligaments against Sunderland in November – their most creative force and a talent who has found greater consistency under Jürgen Klopp. Liverpool's Premier League rise has been based largely on their potent front three so it is no surprise they all feature in the list and Coutinho has climbed 18 places since last year. He has scored 13 goals for his club in 2016, finally secured a regular place alongside his close friend Neymar in the Brazil attack and been regularly linked in Spain with a move to Barcelona. Liverpool, however, want the 24-year-old to sign a new long-term deal.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David de Gea
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It took a few years but De Gea has now ousted Iker Casillas as Spain’s No1 and, at 26, could have another decade in him at that level. He had another exceptional year although it may be remembered for the insufficient repelling of Eder’s free-kick in the Euro 2016 quarter-final against Italy that led Giorgio Chiellini to set Spain’s defeat in motion. That would be harsh; in that game alone De Gea made enough world-class saves to remind everyone of the norm and his form for Manchester United, where a third consecutive player of the year award told its own story, was outstanding. His FA Cup semi-final penalty save from Romelu Lukaku helped ensure a turgid 2015-16 season for the club brought some silverware.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Pepe
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A two-times Champions League winner who has made the team of the tournament at the past three European Championships, Pepe's reputation as a master of football's jet-black arts have probably precluded him from featuring on this list before now. He's a toe-rag – but he's Real Madrid and Portugal's toe-rag and both were delighted to call on the uncompromising defender for their respective marches to European glory. Euro 2016 proved that, as well as being a pantomime villain capable of occasional acts of violence and duplicity, Pepe is no mean footballer. His performance in the final against France was little short of heroic.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thomas Müller
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Despite scoring 20 goals in the Bundesliga and eight in the Champions League in his most prolific season to date, the Germany forward drops 26 places after finishing sixth last year. Still only 27, Müller already has five league titles to his name and is fast approaching the 100-cap mark for his country, although perhaps his versatility works against him when it comes to comparisons with the very best in the game. The departure of Pep Guardiola in the summer also seems to have affected him – it took him 12 appearances to score a league goal under Carlo Ancelotti.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Arturo Vidal
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: After a difficult start to his career at Bayern under Pep Guardiola, the Chilean midfielder proved so important with his drive and determination that the Catalan coach found himself unable to leave him out of the double-winning squad. The 29-year-old continued his fine form in the Copa América, where Chile triumphed on penalties against Argentina for the second time in as many years (Vidal missed his spot-kick, however). This season has been less impressive, as the box-to-box specialist struggles to find full fitness and fend off rumours about off-the-pitch indiscretions.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Harry Kane
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The England striker has not only become a routine destroyer of defences. He has, in the process, wrung three new contracts out of the Tottenham Hotspur chairman, Daniel Levy, since August 2014 – and that is, most assuredly, no mean feat. Kane’s latest deal pays him more than £100,000 a week, making him the best-paid player in the club’s history and reflecting his status as the Premier League’s Golden Boot winner from 2015-16. He has a rare connection with the fans at White Hart Lane, who appreciate his prodigious work-rate and loyalty. With Kane, however, it starts and finishes with the goals.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ivan Rakitić
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Has looked tired and out of place in the last few weeks, raising doubts for the first time since he arrived at Barcelona, but his contribution has been huge since joining the club – not least because of the combination of talent, intelligence and workrate with which he covers the right side, often alone. Won the treble in his first season, a goal in the Champions League final included, and the double in his second. Played every game as Croatia won their group at Euro 2016, finishing ahead of Spain, only to go out to Portugal in the second round, despite him insisting that they had been the better team.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Eden Hazard
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Eden Hazard’s slump to 35th place probably reflects how miserable so much of last season proved to be for the Belgian. A player who had illuminated the Premier League title-winning campaign the year before struggled desperately for form and fitness under José Mourinho and Guus Hiddink. Now playing pain-free again, he is back to his scintillating best from a free role on the left of a front three, scoring and providing goals in a resurgent team under Antonio Conte. His effervescent display against Everton in November was arguably one of the greatest witnessed in the Premier League.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jérôme Boateng
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A year of two halves for the dominant centre-back. Superb in Bayern’s defence during Pep Guardiola’s final six months in charge, the 28-year-old has struggled after the summer. Niggling injuries have played their part and he admitted in December that, frankly, he “was not playing well enough”. He did not take kindly to criticism from Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, however, when the Bayern chief executive said Boateng “needed to come back to earth a little” and spend less time on his PR commitments. “I can only laugh at those comments,” he said.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Paulo Dybala
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The third-highest new entry on this year’s list, it is a safe bet that Dybala will climb further in the years ahead. His former team-mate Paul Pogba has already identified him as a potential future Ballon d’Or winner, as well as giving him the nickname “Square R2” – a reference to the buttons used on a PlayStation game to execute a curling finish. The Argentinian does score a few of those, but to reduce his game to such would be to miss the dribbling, the footwork, the speed of thought and the joy that make him so special.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gerard Piqué
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Defenders rarely get the plaudits in "best player of the year" polls, especially if they play for Barcelona. But the 29-year-old was once more imperious for his hometown club as they picked up yet another league title – the sixth of Piqué's career – with the second meanest defence in La Liga behind Atlético Madrid. His year was slightly marred by "sleevegate", which led to the announcement of his intention to retire from international football after the 2018 World Cup. Spain will be a poorer side without him.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Busquets
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It is some prospect that Busquets, still just 28 but seemingly around forever, probably has five years or so left at the top level – not that he will necessarily be noticed as much as he deserves. It was a fine start to 2016 for Busquets, who was his usual formidably consistent, meticulous self in Barcelona’s latest title win, although things have tailed off slightly since. Spain flopped at Euro 2016 and then, with Barcelona trailing Real in the La Liga race this time, there have been suggestions that his calm, controlled style is not quite as important to Luis Enrique’s side as it used to be. Barcelona are a shade more direct than in previous years and it may be that the long-serving midfielder has to adapt.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Hugo Lloris
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A new entry this year thanks to his quietly crucial role in Tottenham Hotspur's Premier League title challenge and France's progress to the Euro 2016 final. He led his club and his country by example, producing consistently high-grade performances to give confidence to his defenders. He was a key factor in Spurs recording the joint-best defensive record in the Premier League last season, as his shot-stopping prowess foiled many an opponent and his speed off the line enabled his team to defend high. He inspires by setting and demanding high standards and he is among the most reliable goalkeepers in Europe.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Koke
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Koke has stood at the heart of the debate about Atlético’s identity this season, one that is often stripped down and simplified to a single question: where is Koke playing? In the middle of midfield or to the side? Diego Simeone says he has been working on bringing him inside, the key midfielder, for three years now – but still it has not quite happened definitively. They are more creative when he is there but, as the captain Gabi said, more fragile too. Spain, for whom he has 29 caps, are watching closely: a superb player, with vision and creativity, passing skill and an ability to judge what the game needs, but the obsession over finding someone to “be” Xavi perhaps has not helped him.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jan Oblak
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Oblak makes his debut in the 100 firmly ensconced in the top half, but he is only the fifth-highest goalkeeper on the list. Plus ça change for the Slovenian, who remains one of the most underrated players in Europe. He is the ultimate elite level goalkeeper; rather than making a string of saves, playing behind Atlético Madrid’s rugged defence means his greatest asset is concentration, as he has to suddenly awaken to pull something out of the bag. The exception was his remarkable display to keep Bayern at bay in the Champions League semi-final. No wonder Atleti fans barely remember who Thibaut Courtois was.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ángel di María
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It takes a special kind of magic to make £44m seem like a bargain but that is the effect that Di María wrought in his first season at Paris Saint-Germain following his transfer from Manchester United. A misfit at Old Trafford, he became the creative leader of PSG’s team, regularly teeing up goals for team-mates as well as scoring 15 himself in his debut season in France. But, as at United, his performances then dipped and his attitude caused concern, so much so that by December he was being booed by PSG fans.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David Silva
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: David Silva’s excellence sometimes seems in danger of being taken for granted these days. While Manchester City have rued injuries to Sergio Agüero and Kevin De Bruyne in recent times they are simply not the same without the Spaniard, who might be less dynamic but has a wily, scheming creative brain with few parallels. He can thread a ball through the eye of a needle, or turn up in a pocket of space that had seemed sealed off moments previously; he keeps everything ticking, whether from a central position or drifting in from wide, and would arguably be City’s hardest player to replace. A minor criticism would be that the goals, while never that many in number, have dried up in 2016 – only four at the time of writing.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marco Verratti
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Not the Italian’s happiest year even if, after two months out with injury, he returned to the PSG squad in April to claim his fourth Ligue 1 title in a row and then lifted the French League Cup. Injury struck again and ruled him out of Euro 2016. His importance to PSG is such that he signed a contract extension in August and Olivier Giroud took a petty swipe at him in September. Verratti’s red card for being knocked over by the forward was rescinded but his misfortune against Arsenal continued when he scored an own goal at the Emirates Stadium.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Diego Costa
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It is surprising, perhaps, that Chelsea's Brazil-born Spain international forward still finds himself so far down this list given his staggering scoring rate since arriving in the Premier League. Perhaps it is a legacy of last season’s initially angry and ineffective form. Yet he scored 12 in 20 games from Boxing Day 2015, and has started at a sprint this time around with 13 league goals by mid-December. His disciplinary record, too, has improved markedly under Antonio Conte even if he does still lead the line aggressively. A powerhouse of a player, and one of the Premier League's best.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Edinson Cavani
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: His big prize came after winning the Ligue 1 title with PSG, when the club decided against buying a replacement for Zlatan Ibrahimovic and gave the role to Cavani instead. He had craved a return to the central striking berth and, since gaining it, has demonstrated his exceptional movement. His goals-per-game ratio is excellent – for PSG both domestically and in Europe, as well as for Uruguay in the South American World Cup qualifying group – but his rate of misses means he has a staggering blooper reel, too.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marcelo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: On the eve of his 10th anniversary of signing for Real Madrid, Marcelo is beginning to be recognised as a true cornerstone of his team. If locking up top talent like Gareth Bale and Cristiano Ronaldo ahead of the impending Fifa registration ban was important, we should note the left-back was the first to commit in July last year, and nobody at the club is any doubt about just how important that was. More than just an attacking full-back, his poise infield as well as out wide was evident in the march towards a second Champions League title in three years.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mauro Icardi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: There really is never a dull moment with Icardi, who signed a new contract with Internzionale in October before enraging his team's Ultras with a spectacularly ill-conceived autobiography that hit the shelves a week later. So furious was the reaction against one particular passage – in which he reminisced proudly about threatening to hire criminals from Argentina to kill fans who abused him – that he was eventually obliged to get the book republished with the offending passage removed. Yet he retained the captaincy and continues to score goals with rare frequency. He is contributing more to buildup play nowadays, too.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Karim Benzema
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The striker’s omission from the France Euro 2016 squad became a political debate featuring some mean posturing. But one thing everyone agrees on when it comes to Benzema is that he can be a fine player. And he has thrived under the managership of Zinedine Zidane, whom he refers to as “like a big brother”. His conniving with Cristiano Ronaldo and Gareth Bale was among Real Madrid’s key arms in their Champions League triumph, and in December he became only the sixth player to reach the landmark of 50 goals in that competition.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mats Hummels
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Hummels will never outrun a cheetah (or most centre-forwards) but his sub-zero coolness under pressure, intelligent positional play and superlative passing game certainly mark him out as one of the world’s best centre-backs. The 28-year-old captained a fine Dortmund team who finished runners-up in both domestic competitions, caught the eye in Joachim Löw’s Germany team at Euro 2016 and instantly slotted into the Bayern team of Carlo Ancelotti upon his return to his hometown club after eight years with BVB. A steep rise up the rankings (from 75th to 51st) reflects the growing international recognition of his craft.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thiago Silva
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: In September he was recalled to the Brazil squad for the first time in 12 months in recognition of the fact that had fully recovered from injury niggles and regained his best form. That form makes him one of the world's best centre-backs or, as Paolo Maldini once suggested, “the only defender who can change the outcome of a game”. He led PSG to a domestic treble in France and was not to blame for elimination from the Champions League by Manchester City.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Casemiro
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “I feel respected as a player now,” Casemiro said in April, and these days it would take a curious argument to disparage him. His appearance just outside the top 50 in this list, from nowhere, speaks of the impact he has had since becoming a fixture in the Real Madrid side in the latter days of Rafael Benítez and then, crucially, under Zinedine Zidane. Casemiro is the water-carrier, the positional conscience, behind a Real side laden with attacking talent and he gives them crucial balance they had missed in the past. He recycles the ball adroitly and a tactical foul is rarely beyond him when Real are out of possession; Zidane terms the 24-year-old “fundamental” to his European champions and few would now disagree.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Renato Sanches
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: What a stunning impact it was at Euro 2016 from Sanches, whose contributions for Portugal included a searing equaliser in the quarter-final against Poland – making him the youngest player to score in a European Championship knockout stage – and a shootout penalty in the same game. Sanches added skill and a crucial change of gear to a midfield short on stardust; he ended up a champion and it is unlikely to be his last major honour. He joined Bayern Munich in a £29m deal from Benfica a month before the tournament, with Manchester United among other interested parties. Opportunities this season have not come freely but, at 19 and with a formidable set of physical and technical gifts, time is on his side.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Keylor Navas
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It was a kick in the teeth for Real Madrid when, in September 2015, their move for David de Gea fell through. They could not prise him from Manchester United last summer either but the form of Navas, who had been mooted to move in the opposite direction, has made it seem rather less consequential. He has not been quite as sharp at times this season – perhaps owing to ankle surgery that ruled him out of the early weeks – and has competition from the improved Kiko Casilla, but at his best Navas is the most alert of shot-stoppers, with excellent footwork and a strong command of his posts. Having won the Champions League, he now looks on course for a first La Liga title.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Philipp Lahm
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A big faller in this year's top 100, he can count himself unlucky. Having already retired from international football after leading Germany to the 2014 World Cup, Lahm's plan to hang up his boots for good at the end of next season are still in place despite yet another Bundesliga title to add to his collection. Carlo Ancelotti's arrival has seen him switch back to the right-back position he excelled in for so many years, having mainly played in midfield and even on the wing under Pep Guardiola. The Manchester City manager has described Lahm as the most intelligent player he has ever worked with and there is no doubt Bayern will miss him when he is gone.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Henrikh Mkhitaryan
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: José Mourinho has received plenty of criticism for his apparent coldness towards Mkhitaryan, although the Armenian midfielder recently took the blame for his slow start at Manchester United. “The problem wasn’t him, it was me,” Mkhitaryan said. Even so, it was not easy to understand his absence from a side crying out for more creativity. Quick, elusive and intelligent, Mkhitaryan was superb in the Bundesliga for Borussia Dortmund last season, which is why he has shot up by 20 places, and he has teased United with glimpses of class in the past month. They will be aching for more in 2017.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Toby Alderweireld
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: When the Belgium centre-half joined Tottenham Hotspur in the summer of 2015, he found a defence that was prone to individual and collective lapses. By the end of last season, they had conceded the joint-fewest goals in the Premier League. Alderweireld was the only new addition to the defensive unit. The heir apparent to Vincent Kompany at international level, Alderweireld brings assurance on the ball and the ability to read and win the one-on-one duels. He is also a threat from set pieces. For a long time, he had drifted under the radar in terms of recognition. He is no longer the unsung hero.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Kévin Gameiro
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: France were not what they should have been at Euro 2016 and one of the reasons for that was flawed management by Didier Deschamps, whose most spectacular bungle was omitting Gameiro from the squad, especially with Karim Benzema exiled. Gameiro proved that when he was belatedly called up for the World Cup qualifiers, instantly forming a deadly understanding with Antoine Griezmann. That came as no surprise to anyone who had watched this clever poacher fire Sevilla to another Europa League conquest and earn a move to Atlético Madrid.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Joshua Kimmich
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Such a versatile player, it is no surprise that he has been dubbed the new Philipp Lahm. Forced his way into the Bayern starting XI under Pep Guardiola and can play at full-back, in central defence or in midfield. Towards the end of the year he was starting to score goals as well for club and country – and he is only 21. Kimmich learned so much from Guardiola – and the respect was mutual. “I’ve told him that he’s perhaps one of the best centre-backs in the world,” Guardiola said. “He’s got the desire, the will, the passion. He’s got absolutely everything.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David Alaba
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The year started with David Alaba moonlighting as a very capable centre-back for Bayern Munich under the auspices of chief player-reinventor Pep Guardiola. The 24-year-old did well enough to help the Bavarian club reach their fourth league title in a row but a disastrous Euro 2016 proved the first real setback of his career. Alaba, the outstanding player of his generation in Austria, failed to inspire his team in a central midfield role. Austria crashed out in the group stage after two defeats and a 0-0 draw against Portugal, the eventual championship winners. The new season has brought a return to form in his customary full-back position at club level but the poor showings in France have seen his stock decline.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Javier Mascherano
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Are we starting to see the first signs of decline in one of the most tenacious players of the modern era? The 32-year-old has tumbled 37 places in the rankings and has not looked entirely comfortable in defence this season. Perhaps that was why he was itching for a return to central midfield in the summer. Mascherano has rarely let anyone down as a centre-back, but he has come in for criticism recently. However, he feels that he has been unfairly singled out by people seeking scapegoats for Barcelona’s faltering defence of their title.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Douglas Costa
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A significant fall this year for Costa, an outstanding talent whose form has been more mercurial than consistent in 2016. He was unable to have a significant influence at the back end of last season in Bayern’s Champions League exit to Atlético Madrid and contributions have been fitful since the summer, too – although there have been signs of a return to his best in recent weeks as Bayern themselves have gathered speed under Carlo Ancelotti. Costa has generally operated on the left of the attack but is comfortable on the other flank, too; a run of brilliance could make the difference on all fronts for Bayern in the coming months.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gabriel Jesus
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: You would back Gabriel Jesus to make quite an entrance when his move to Manchester City goes through, at last, next month. His early impact for the Brazilian senior team, for whom he has scored four times since making his debut in September, showed he is in little mood to wait around and he had already scored three times for their Under-23s at the Olympics. Jesus won Brazil’s Golden Ball award for 2016 after scoring 12 goals to help Palmeiras win the title; he has a remarkable finishing range, as a deft chip for Brazil against Venezuela showed, and a level of pace to scorch the most fireproof of defences. “I told them it’s hard without the [number] 33,” said Jesus recently, explaining the shirt he hopes to take at City – but most things have come easily so far for the 19-year-old and perhaps Brazil, who seem to be on the rise, really do have their next big star.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mohamed Salah
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Never really given a chance at Stamford Bridge, the Egypt forward has settled in well to life in the Italian capital and has followed up his return of 14 goals in Serie A last season with eight already this term. The former Basel player has also been in scintillating form for Egypt this year having scored five times in six appearances as the Pharaohs qualified for the Africa Cup of Nations for the first time since 2010, when they won the tournament for a third time in succession. He could be on the rise again next year if he can inspire them to another victory.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Giorgio Chiellini
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Softly spoken, but thunderous in the challenge, Chiellini relishes his role as the aggressor in Juventus's and Italy's first-choice back three. He scored the opening goal in the Azzurri's Euro 2016 win over Spain, but it was not this memory that caused his former team-mate Álvaro Morata to celebrate news that the centre-back would be suspended for a rematch in World Cup qualifying this October. "I want such good things for Giorgio, I am really fond of him," said the Spaniard. "But I can honestly say that my ankles feel gratitude for him getting that red card in Israel."

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Aritz Aduriz
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The striker is now in his mid-30s but rather than slowing down he is in the form of his life. His goalscoring record for Athletic Bilbao over the past two-and-a-half seasons is phenomenal: he hit 26 in 2014-15, 36 in 2015-16 and started 2016-17 in a similar fashion. Against Genk in the Europa League in November he managed to score all of his side’s five goals in a 5-3 win. He returned to the Spain fold and made the Euro 2016 squad ahead of Diego Costa, and in November become the country’s oldest scorer.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Laurent Koscielny
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: He has developed into one of the Premier League's most reliable centre-backs and is essential to Arsenal's solidity, perhaps the club's most important player along with Alexis Sánchez and Mesut Özil. Strong in the air and the tackle, shrewd in his positioning and courageously committed, Koscielny has helped Shkodran Mustafi's integration into English football and the pair have formed a sturdy partnership. The Frenchman, who started all seven of his country's games at Euro 2016, is also a serious threat in opposing boxes, though his overhead kick goal against Southampton in September was not exactly representative of his body of work.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sadio Mané
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Jürgen Klopp’s mistake was ultimately Liverpool’s gain when they acquired Mané in a £34m deal this summer. Klopp believes the Senegal international would have cost much more had he arrived via Borussia Dortmund but he spurned the chance to sign the 24-year-old for his former club two years ago. "I could have punched myself," the manager admitted. “So I already knew that the next chance I have, I would take it.” Mané has settled seamlessly, his pace and unselfishness on the ball a feature of a well-balanced attack and justifying Liverpool's decision to switch their attention to Southampton when Mario Götze prevaricated over a move to Anfield.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Miralem Pjanic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: One of just two players to reach double figures for both goals and assists in Serie A last season, it is easy to see why Juventus were so eager to steal Pjanic away from Roma in the summer. The Bosnian struggled initially to find his spot within his new team, but the finesse in his technique and his touch have never been in doubt. In open play Pjanic is more subtle than spectacular, but he strikes a dead-ball as well as anyone in the world – hardly surprising, given that he learned from the legendary Juninho Pernambucano at Lyon.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Álvaro Morata
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: At his best, Morata can look like a complete centre-forward. One performance this year, in his final European game for Juventus, stands out – when he gave Bayern Munich’s defence a pasting for 72 minutes of their Champions League round-of-16 second leg at the Allianz Arena before being replaced and watching his side collapse almost instantly. He came off the bench to score their winning goal in the Coppa Italia final against AC Milan two months later; despite not always being a guaranteed starter for Juventus he seemed a good option for his old club, Real Madrid, when they bought him back in June and he has contributed well enough so far. Morata also scored three times in Spain’s ill-fated Euro 2016 campaign.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Kasper Schmeichel
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Following in his legendary father’s footsteps, the Dane had a vital role in Leicester City's title win. Schmeichel always had potential as a youngster, but he did not seem destined for the very top when he was playing in the lower leagues. Yet he excelled after Leicester’s promotion to the Premier League in 2014 and came of age last season, a formidable presence behind Claudio Ranieri’s back four. His fine form has continued into this campaign – his wondrous late save against FC Copenhagen in the Champions League took the breath away – and Leicester have missed him during his absence with a broken hand.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Aaron Ramsey
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Arsenal midfielder was determined to be noticed at Euro 2016, and he dyed his hair peroxide blonde. It was his performances for Wales that demanded the attention and the only disappointment was his suspension for the semi-final against Portugal. How Wales missed him. Ramsey was an easy choice for the Uefa Team of the Tournament and, by extension, this list, too. He has not always hit the heights for Arsenal, with injury and Arsène Wenger’s tendency to play him at right midfield, rather than in his favoured central role, holding him back. But he showed what he was capable of at the European Championship with his precision passing and outstanding movement.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Raphaël Guerreiro
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “Raphaël Guerreiro is way too versatile to play just one position,” said the Borussia Dortmund manager, Thomas Tuchel, of his new signing from Lorient a month into the season. He had already seen the proof. Guerreiro had spent the summer standing out at left-back for Portugal, his speed and technical attributes marking him out without necessarily getting their fullest airing in a relatively conservative side. Tuchel has sought to make the most of Guerreiro’s gifts, fielding him in central and left-midfield roles as well as his more familiar position, and the 22-year-old has shown outstanding application in them all. He may not yet be the new Philipp Lahm, as one or two excitable commentaries have had it, but he has a fighting chance.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Rui Patrício
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Now in his 10th campaign as Sporting Clube de Portugal’s first-choice goalkeeper, the 28-year-old has always been adored inside the Estádio José Alvalade. His performance for Portugal in the Euro 2016 final, however, found him a whole new host of admirers around the world. Patrício was immaculate against France throughout in Saint-Denis; never under siege, but unfussy, tidy and decisive at the key moments. His distribution, which certainly separated him from the best goalkeepers in the world in past years, has also steadily improved as he has stayed with Sporting and helped his boyhood team to become competitive again.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Roberto Firmino
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Brazil international is a new entry on our list, reflecting his progress in a year when he became the point of Liverpool's forward line, ousting Daniel Sturridge in the process, and demonstrated why Jürgen Klopp had such belief in the potential of the squad he inherited from Brendan Rodgers. Klopp saw it as a coup when Liverpool landed the Brazilian for £29m from Hoffenheim while he was on sabbatical, believing they had signed a player fundamental to the manager's approach. “He is a connecting player,” the former Borussia Dortmund coach explained. “A finisher, a fighter, the first defender. A lot of things he is good at are very important for us.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Yannick Carrasco
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: As celebrations go, the rising star of Belgian football could not have planned his any better. The kiss planted on girlfriend Noemie Happart’s lips after his equaliser for Atlético Madrid in the Champions League final against their bitter rivals announced the 23-year-old on the world stage after a stop-start debut season in Spain. Carrasco has now established himself as a regular starter for both club and country, with nine goals during a purple patch in October and November confirming his immense talent. Expect him to improve on this position next year if he maintains his rate of progress.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Dani Alves
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “Who remembers Dani Alves now?” asked the early-season headlines, remembering Dani Alves. A few weeks later and they really, really remembered him. Some were keen to see him go but they miss him now, even if they don’t always admit it. At the start, Sergi Roberto was playing well at full-back, but he has been exposed in recent weeks in a way in which, however much people criticised Alves’s supposed inability to defend, rarely happened with the Brazilian. Barcelona miss his creativity, energy and attitude, too. Football does, in fact, since he suffered a broken leg with Juventus.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Nani
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The winger’s return to the 100 is recognition of his growing maturity as he hits 30. Nani has been quietly impressive since leaving Manchester United in 2014, but it’s his exploits for Portugal that have really caught the eye. Perhaps it is fate that Fernando Santos solved their perennial centre-forward problem by simply repositioning a couple of wingers, but Nani was integral to their triumph at Euro 2016. Allowed to use his natural gifts more spontaneously, rather than overthinking things, he provided vital support to Cristiano Ronaldo as second striker in the Seleção’s 4-4-2 and stood out like never before.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gianluigi Donnarumma
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: When Gianluigi Buffon finally calls it a day, his successor will be ready at hand. Even by the exacting measures set by the incumbent Italy No1, Donnarumma is ahead of schedule: while Buffon made his national team debut three months shy of his 20th birthday, there was Donnarumma, in September, replacing his idol at half-time of a friendly with France at the age of 17 years, 189 days. That seemed symbolic and although the transition will not occur yet it is unlikely to be too long: at 6ft 5in Donnarumma has an extraordinary physique but equally impressive is the command of his penalty area that such a young goalkeeper exerts each week for AC Milan. “My son, at 17, still seemed like a boy,” admitted Buffon’s father, admiringly, in October; Donnarumma is already standing tall among adults.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Claudio Bravo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Under fire in England, but highly rated in Spain and South America, the goalkeeper has had a curious year. Regular watchers of Manchester City might find Bravo’s rise in the rankings difficult to understand. Bought by Pep Guardiola as a replacement for Joe Hart because of his passing ability, Bravo has often looked uncertain, particularly during that traumatic Camp Nou return in October, yet it is too early to write him off. Having helped Barcelona win La Liga last season, he was Chile’s hero in the summer when their Copa América final against Argentina went to penalties.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marek Hamsik
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Slovakia’s Euro 2016 performance ended up being a footnote but one moment stood out. There was little evident danger when Hamsik picked up a short corner in the group stage against Russia but his subsequent finish, running into the box before thudding an angled effort in off the post, was one of the tournament’s best goals. Hamsik is his country’s one world-class player and offers similar gifts to Napoli, where he will have completed a decade at the end of the season. His goalscoring output, always healthy, nears one in three this term and there are few playmakers around with his mixture of elegance and dynamism.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Miguel Borja
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: At the start of this year, Borja seemed to be fading from view after an early crack at Europe. The striker had moved from Cortuluá, a provincial Colombia club, to Livorno as a 20-year-old in 2013, a loan move eventually becoming permanent, but achieved little in Italy and returned to his old team at something close to square one. But a six-month spell that brought 19 goals in 21 games earned him a move to Atlético Nacional and then things really lifted off: on his debut he scored twice against Sao Paulo in the Copa Liberatadores semi-finals, repeating the trick in the second leg and earning the team a final against Independiente del Valle – in which he produced the winner. Borja is strong, quick and a varied, explosive finisher; Europe may well call again soon.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Blaise Matuidi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Seemingly bored by sweeping the board in France every year, Matuidi was close to leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer but eventually stayed. At first he was demoted to the bench but after a month of the new season the club's new manager, Unai Emery, restored him to the starting lineup and even made him captain for several matches, which was acknowledgment of the midfielder's leadership skills and his aptitude to aptitude to play the frenzied pressing style demanded by the manager while also being tidy in possession and a goal threat. Didier Deschamps trusts in him, too.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ilkay Gündogan
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It was mid-September before Gündogan, who had been struck down by a knee injury that scuppered his Euro 2016 and delayed the start of his Manchester City career, could show why Pep Guardiola had been so keen to bring him from Borussia Dortmund. By 1 November he had scored five times for City, including two in the win over Barcelona that was the clearest signal yet of what Guardiola's team might become. Gündogan had been known more for his metronomic passing and anticipation in deeper areas of the midfield before then, but that night he was ferocious in the press and clinical when chances came his way. Guardiola feels he can get even more from Gündogan, who is certainly intelligent enough to take in his manager's instructions. His 2017 may be tougher after sustaining the injury against Watford in December that could derail his season.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Juan Mata
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: You sometimes wonder how it must feel to be Juan Mata, who often seems a quixotic presence in a football world whose top end is beset by cynicism. He was widely considered not long for Manchester United upon the arrival of José Mourinho, under whom he had fallen from favour at Chelsea, but his influence at the club had already been keenly felt. It was his goal – one of 10 last season – that rescued United from defeat in the FA Cup final against Crystal Palace and he has made key contributions this time around too. A lack of pace has tended to be his biggest drawback and how he fares under Mourinho now that an invigorated Henrikh Mkhitaryan is hitting form may define his medium-term future.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: James Rodríguez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Rodríguez has the ignominy of making the biggest fall among those who have retained a place in the Top 100 this year. It has been a year of fits and starts for the Colombian, who watched all 120 minutes of Real Madrid's Champions League win from the bench and has since struggled to muster any real consistency under Zinedine Zidane, although there have been a few more starts recently. He remains a player of brilliant range and vision but may move on for more of a centre-stage role in the next year and Paris Saint-Germain, who have a vacancy for a star, have been among those linked.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Raheem Sterling
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It has been an up and down year for Raheem Sterling, who drops 26 places from his position on last year's roll of honour. Unfairly scapegoated for what was a collective England failure at Euro 2016 in an alarming number of tabloid splashes with sinister racial undertones, Sterling recovered from a noticeable dip in form last season to become a revelation for Manchester City. The switch seems to have been flicked by the mother of all Pep talks from a new club manager who employed the highly scientific motivational technique of ringing a kid whose confidence is shot just to tell him that he is great.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Arjen Robben
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: He’s the wrong side of 30 (32, to be precise), breaks down more than a clapped-out VW Beetle, he spends as much time on the ground as nice piece of parquet flooring and can still do only one single trick. That trick, however, a full-speed diagonal inside run from the right, followed by a curled, powerful left-foot shot into the top corner, remains impossible to defend against. Carlo Ancelotti has given the easily-flying Dutchman a new lease of life at Bayern, where Robben continues to elevate his team to another level in any game. It’s just a shame he doesn’t play more of them – hence his steep fall in this year's ranking.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Dele Alli
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Tottenham Hotspur midfielder is one of the hottest prospects in Europe: one of those rare talents who can light up a game with a single moment – normally a trick, feint or nutmeg. His rise has been startling. At the end of 2014-15, he had won promotion from League One with MK Dons; at the end of last season, he was the PFA's young player of the year, having scored 10 Premier League goals and been central to Tottenham's title challenge. Sir Alex Ferguson has described him as the best midfielder he has seen since Paul Gascoigne. Already an England regular, Alli's game is built on technique, fitness, audacity and fearlessness.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Adrien Silva
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Another newcomer to the 100, the midfielder was one from the Sporting production line that could have easily slipped through the cracks, sent out on loan before coming a regular first-teamer in 2013 as the club recovered their homegrown focus. At Euro 2016, Silva found his place; the blue-collar player for the ultimate blue-collar team, not spectacular at anything but highly competent at everything. He is an accomplished passer, tackler and a useful goalscorer – and he even turned his hand to specifically muzzling Luka Modric in the last-16 game with Croatia. Little wonder Leicester wanted to bring him to the Premier League.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thibaut Courtois
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Belgian goalkeeper had been such a consistent performer in the title-winning season of 2014-15 that his toils last term, when progress was interrupted initially by a knee injury and, more latterly, an apparent pining for life in Spain, damaged his reputation. That would explain his plummet by 56 places in this list. But he is steadily recovering his form this term at Chelsea, buoyed by the team's far more solid backline. He remains a fine shot-stopper but may suffer from not being Petr Cech, to whom all goalkeepers at this club will surely be compared for years ahead.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Fernandinho
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A player who believes that footballers should engage more with the public, judging by the way he ushered Chelsea’s Cesc Fàbregas into the crowd at the Etihad Stadium. Such admirable behaviour must be the explanation for his emergence on the list although it should also be pointed out that the Brazilian has been a solid presence in Manchester City’s midfield, rising above the torpor as the Manuel Pellegrini era stuttered to an unsatisfactory end and impressing Pep Guardiola with his dynamism. He chips in with important goals as well, scoring when City beat Liverpool in the League Cup final.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Alexandre Lacazette
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Back in January he scored the first goal at Lyon's new stadium and that signalled lift-off in a season in which, until then, he had failed to reach the heights of the previous campaign. He eventually ended the Ligue 1 campaign with 21 goals, placing (a distant) second to Zlatan Ibrahimovic in the league's scoring charts. That was not enough to convince Didier Deschamps to include him in the Euro 2016 squad. After a summer off in which Lyon rejected Arsenal's advances, he returned to action in style, scoring a hat-trick on the opening day of the new season. Strong, rapid, two-footed and keen-eyed, Lacazette is a striker with no major weakness.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Éver Banega
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For a player whose career once seemed to be spinning out of control – caught pleasuring himself on a webcam one moment, running over his own foot at a petrol station the next – the story has come full circle. Banega has been a model of control these past two seasons, on the pitch at least, his patient midfield construction providing the platform for consecutive Europa League titles at Sevilla. Whether he can make the same impact at Inter, where he has struggled together with his new team-mates through a chaotic start to the season, remains to be seen.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Francesco Totti
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: You would have needed a heart of stone not to be moved when, in April and a glorious Roma career seemingly winding down in unsatisfactory fashion, Totti came off the bench 86 minutes into a match against Torino and straight away turned a 2-1 deficit into a 3-2 win. The celebrations were chaotic and tearful; those two goals were a reminder of the theatre he has brought to the Giallorossi over a period spanning almost two decades and perhaps contributed to his signing a one-year contract in June. That took him past his 40th birthday, celebrated in September, and although Totti is these days used sparingly he appears tempted to carry on further. “Why stop?” he asked last month. “I was taken for finished last year.” Even in cameos, the oldest player on this list remains a master of his era.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Santi Cazorla
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: When Cazorla plays, Arsenal play. The little Spaniard has long established himself as the club's tempo-setter-in-chief; the man at the heart of those passing rhythms, and his easiness on the eye, particularly in tight spaces, means that he is invariably feted, even after a trying year – in which injuries have bitten hard. His absence over the second half of last season was held up as a major reason for Arsenal's failure to win the Premier League title. He is down two places from his position on the 2015 list; where might he he have finished with better luck on the fitness front?

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thiago Alcântara
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The son of the former Brazil international Mazinho missed the best part of two important years of his development with a troublesome right knee but has now become a regular in the Bayern Munich midfield. Yet any hopes Pep Guardiola may have had of buying him for a second time after luring him to Munich from Barcelona were dealt a blow when he split from his agent brother Pere in October, with Alcântara's father now set to take over. At his best, he remains one of the best passers in the business but now needs to take more games by the scruff of the neck in order to move to the next level.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Julian Weigl
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The young German central midfielder is a newcomer on the list after a superb year with Borussia Dortmund. Still only 21, he is mature beyond his years and already capable of dictating Bundesliga games with his excellent passing. The Nationalmannschaft coach Joachim Löw is a huge fan, too, and gave the youngster his debut and included him in the Euro 2016 squad (although Weigl did not make an appearance in France). “He is a very intelligent young man,” says Thomas Tuchel, his coach at Borussia. “We’re delighted with him – with his sporting development and his personality. He has played an incredible amount of games for us in the last year.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ousmane Dembélé
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Voted Ligue 1's young player of the year at the end of the 2015-16 season after scoring 12 goals in 26 appearances for Rennes, the teenager picked Borussia Dortmund from the array of suitors at his door in the summer. The wisdom of that purchase is already clear, as Dembélé has showcased his exceptional talent in the Bundesliga and in the Champions League even if he has not yet fully refined his finishing. His balance, footwork and change of pace are delightful and his conniving with the rest of Dortmund's brigade of attackers make the German side one of the most spectacular in the world. Dembélé has added to France's awesome armoury after becoming a senior international in September.
